CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: The microstructure of blend films of the copolymers with fullerene derivatives is known to have a large effect on the charge transport properties and the corresponding efficiencies of PSCs. Here , the atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) was applied to investigate the morphology of the blend film of the polymer : PC 70 BM fabricated from CB and DCB solutions , respectively , as shown in Fig. 3. For PDTP-BT : PC 70 BM , both CB and DCB gave the films with obvious phase separation with a root mean square ( RMS ) of 2.222 nm and 0.880 nm , respectively , which might be due to the poor miscibility of the two materials. For PDTP - DTBT and PDTP-DT2BT , the blend film of polymer / PC 70 BM spin - coated from CB was also rough , but the blend films fabricated from DCB displayed a much smoother surface with a RMS of 0.188 nm and 0.259 nm , respectively. This smaller roughness of the blend film indicates that the domain size of the phase separation of the donor - acceptor interpenetrating network could be reduced , which could be beneficial for the exciton charge separation and charge transport. These results indicate that the morphologies of these polymers with PC 70 BM are quite sensitive to the solvents used for device processing and the introduction of a thienyl spacer could improve the miscibility . The photovoltaic properties of the three copolymers PDTP-BT , PDTP - DTBT and PDTP-DT2BT were studied by fabricating bulk heterojunction BHJ - type PSCs with a conventional sandwich configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC 70 BM / Ca / Al. The effective areas of the PSCs , contributing to photocurrent , were defined using a metal photomask during irradiation with simulated solar light. The devices were optimized by changing many factors , such as the ratio of the donor and the acceptor , the thickness of blend films and the cathode metal. The best performance was obtained with the thickness of the active layer of 80-90 nm , the copolymers : PC 70 BM ratio of 1 : 2 ( by weight ) and the Ca / Al used as the cathode. Fig. 4 shows the J-V curves of the optimized PSCs based on the three polymers under illumination of AM 1.5 simulated solar light ( 100 mW cm^-2 ). The PSCs with two kinds of solvents CB and DCB for the spin - coating of the active layers were investigated , and the corresponding photovoltaic parameters of the devices open - circuit voltage ( V OC ) , short - circuit current density ( J SC ) , fill factor ( FF ) and PCE are summarized in Table 2. When CB was used as the solvent , all the combinations showed a relatively low PCE of 0.87% , 1.97% and 1.92% in the devices with PDTP-BT : PC 70 BM , PDTP - DTBT : PC 70 BM and PDTP-DT2BT : PC 70 BM respectively.

Let's think step by step.

1. PC 70 BM: This is a copolymer and acts as an acceptor material in the blend films used for polymer solar cells (PSCs).
2. CB: This is a solvent used for fabricating blend films of the copolymers with fullerene derivatives. It is used to dissolve the copolymers and fullerene derivatives before spin-coating them onto a substrate to form the blend film.
3. DCB: This is another solvent used for fabricating blend films of the copolymers with fullerene derivatives. It is also used to dissolve the copolymers and fullerene derivatives before spin-coating them onto a substrate to form the blend film.
4. PC 70 BM: This copolymer is mentioned again later in the paragraph as a component of the bulk heterojunction BHJ-type PSCs with a conventional sandwich configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC 70 BM / Ca / Al.
5. PDTP-BT, PDTP - DTBT, and PDTP-DT2BT: These are the three copolymers used in the study. They are used as donor materials in the blend films and PSCs.
6. PEDOT : PSS: This is a material used as the hole transport layer in the PSCs.
7. Ca / Al: This is the cathode used in the PSCs. Ca is used as the electron transport layer and Al is used as the top electrode.

These are the "Material Name" entities in the given paragraph.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Material Name.

Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name".

Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| PC 70 BM |
| CB |
| DCB |
| PDTP-BT |
| PDTP - DTBT |
| PDTP-DT2BT |
| PEDOT : PSS |
| Ca / Al |

PN.content:
Please identify the Property Names of materials in the following paragraph.

Paragraph: The microstructure of blend films of the copolymers with fullerene derivatives is known to have a large effect on the charge transport properties and the corresponding efficiencies of PSCs. Here , the atomic force microscopy ( AFM ) was applied to investigate the morphology of the blend film of the polymer : PC 70 BM fabricated from CB and DCB solutions , respectively , as shown in Fig. 3. For PDTP-BT : PC 70 BM , both CB and DCB gave the films with obvious phase separation with a root mean square ( RMS ) of 2.222 nm and 0.880 nm , respectively , which might be due to the poor miscibility of the two materials. For PDTP - DTBT and PDTP-DT2BT , the blend film of polymer / PC 70 BM spin - coated from CB was also rough , but the blend films fabricated from DCB displayed a much smoother surface with a RMS of 0.188 nm and 0.259 nm , respectively. This smaller roughness of the blend film indicates that the domain size of the phase separation of the donor - acceptor interpenetrating network could be reduced , which could be beneficial for the exciton charge separation and charge transport. These results indicate that the morphologies of these polymers with PC 70 BM are quite sensitive to the solvents used for device processing and the introduction of a thienyl spacer could improve the miscibility . The photovoltaic properties of the three copolymers PDTP-BT , PDTP - DTBT and PDTP-DT2BT were studied by fabricating bulk heterojunction BHJ - type PSCs with a conventional sandwich configuration of ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer : PC 70 BM / Ca / Al. The effective areas of the PSCs , contributing to photocurrent , were defined using a metal photomask during irradiation with simulated solar light. The devices were optimized by changing many factors , such as the ratio of the donor and the acceptor , the thickness of blend films and the cathode metal. The best performance was obtained with the thickness of the active layer of 80-90 nm , the copolymers : PC 70 BM ratio of 1 : 2 ( by weight ) and the Ca / Al used as the cathode. Fig. 4 shows the J-V curves of the optimized PSCs based on the three polymers under illumination of AM 1.5 simulated solar light ( 100 mW cm^-2 ). The PSCs with two kinds of solvents CB and DCB for the spin - coating of the active layers were investigated , and the corresponding photovoltaic parameters of the devices open - circuit voltage ( V OC ) , short - circuit current density ( J SC ) , fill factor ( FF ) and PCE are summarized in Table 2. When CB was used as the solvent , all the combinations showed a relatively low PCE of 0.87% , 1.97% and 1.92% in the devices with PDTP-BT : PC 70 BM , PDTP - DTBT : PC 70 BM and PDTP-DT2BT : PC 70 BM respectively.

Let's think step by step.

1. The microstructure of blend films: This refers to the physical arrangement and composition of the copolymers and fullerene derivatives in the blend film.
2. Charge transport properties: This refers to the ability of the blend film to facilitate the movement of charged particles (electrons and holes) through it.
3. Corresponding efficiencies of PSCs (polymer solar cells): This refers to the overall energy conversion efficiency of the solar cells that utilize the blend films as the active layer.
4. Morphology of the blend film: This refers to the physical shape and structure of the blend film.
5. Root mean square (RMS): This is a measure of the roughness of the blend film.
6. Phase separation: This refers to the separation of the copolymer and fullerene derivative into distinct domains within the blend film.
7. Domain size of the phase separation: This refers to the physical size of the distinct domains of the copolymer and fullerene derivative in the blend film.
8. Photovoltaic properties: This refers to the ability of the solar cells to convert light into electrical energy.
9. Active layer: This refers to the layer in the solar cell that is responsible for absorbing light and generating charge carriers.
10. Copolymers: These are the polymer materials that are used in the blend film.
11. PC 70 BM: This is a fullerene derivative material that is used in the blend film.
12. Open-circuit voltage (Voc): This is a measure of the maximum voltage that can be generated by the solar cell.
13. Short-circuit current density (Jsc): This is a measure of the maximum current that can be generated by the solar cell.
14. Fill factor (FF): This is a measure of the overall efficiency of the solar cell.
15. Power conversion efficiency (PCE): This is a measure of the overall energy conversion efficiency of the solar cell.
16. Spin-coating: This is a method used to deposit thin films onto a substrate.
17. Solvents: These are liquids used to dissolve the copolymers and fullerene derivatives to form the blend film.
18. CB and DCB: These are solvents used in the spin-coating process.
19. Ratio of the donor and the acceptor: This refers to the relative amounts of the copolymer (donor) and fullerene derivative (acceptor) used in the blend film.
20. Thickness of blend films: This refers to the physical thickness of the blend film.
21. Cathode metal: This refers to the metal used for the back electrode of the solar cell.
22. Ca / Al: This refers to a specific combination of metals used for the cathode.
23. J-V curves: These are graphs that show the current density (J) versus voltage (V) characteristics of the solar cell.
24. Simulated solar light: This is a light source that mimics the spectrum of sunlight.
25. Effective areas of the PSCs: These are the areas of the solar cells that contribute to photocurrent generation.
26. Metal photomask: This is a mask used to define the effective areas of the solar cells during irradiation with simulated solar light.
Please remove irrelevant entities and only keep the entities that clearly refer to Property Name of Material.

1. Morphology of the blend film
2. Root mean square (RMS)
3. Phase separation
4. Domain size of the phase separation
5. Photovoltaic properties
6. Active layer
7. Copolymers

11. Fill factor (FF)
12. Power conversion efficiency (PCE)

17. Ca / Al

1. "a root mean square (RMS) of 2.222 nm" - RMS value of 2.222 nanometers for the blend film of PC 70 BM fabricated from CB solution.
